solution.p:
To find the direction of friction in rolling problems, it is often helpful to ask:
What is the object's acceleration?
What is the object's angular acceleration?
What direction does friction need to be in order that the net force and net torque are consistent with the acceleration and angular acceleration? This is the approach used below.

solution.p: In both cases friction and the engine/brakes provide oppositely directed torques, but the engine/brake torque is bigger. The engine/brakes are mostly responsible for angular acceleration , and friction is directly responsible for the acceleration.

ul.li: When the car begins to accelerate at the green light, the angular velocity of the wheels begins to increase in the clockwise direction. There is a net clockwise torque. We suspect that the engine provides this clockwise torque.

Friction is the only external force on the car, and must be responsible for the car's rightward acceleration. Since there is no relative motion between the tires and the road (rolling without slipping) the force is static friction to the right.
Friction provides a counterclockwise torque, but the net torque is clockwise. So the torque provided by the engire must be clockwise, as we suspected.

When the car begins to slow down (accelerate leftward) at the red light, the clockwise angular velocity of the wheels begins to decrease. There is a net counterclockwise torque. We suspect that the brakes provides this counterclockwise torque.

Friction is the only external force on the car, and must be responsible for the car's leftward acceleration. Since there is no relative motion between the tires and the road (rolling without slipping) the force is static friction to the left.
Friction provides a clockwise torque, but the net torque is counterclockwise. So the torque provided by the engire must be counterclockwise, as we suspected.

problem.p: A disk of mass \(m_1\) and radius \(r_1\) is tied to a block of mass \(m_3\) by an ideal rope. The rope wraps around a pully of mass \(m_2\) and radius \(r_2\) with no slipping between the rope and the pulley. The disk is sitting on a rough surface with coefficient of friction \(\mu\).
The center of mass acceleration of blocks \(m_1\), and \(m_3\) are \(a_1\), and \(a_3\) respectively, whereas the angular acceleration of \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are \(\alpha_1\) and \(\alpha_2\).

em.p: For each of the constraining conditions indicated in the figure, choose the equation(s) that the condition implies.

ul.li: Each condition may imply multiple equations, or may imply none of the given equations.
If an equation is not implied by any of the conditions, do not choose that equation.

td.p: rolling without slipping: Fundamentally, the rolling without slipping constraint means there is no relative velocity between the disk's contact point and the surface on which it rolls. When the surface is at rest, as here, this reduces to \(a_1=\alpha_1 r_1\).

rough surface: The disk accelerates to the right and rolls without slipping. Friction is the force responsible for this acceleration. However, since the ball rolls without slipping, it is static friction that acts. The maximum value of static friction is \(\mu_s m_1 g\), but static friction need only be less than this maximal value\[F_{\textrm{friction}} \leq \mu_s m_1 g\]

problem.p: A disk of mass \(m_1\) and radius \(r_1\) is tied to a block of mass \(m_3\) by an ideal rope. The rope wraps around a pully of mass \(m_2\) and radius \(r_2\) with no slipping between the rope and the pulley. The disk is sitting on a rough surface with coefficient of friction \(\mu\).
The center of mass acceleration of blocks \(m_1\), and \(m_3\) are \(a_1\), and \(a_3\) respectively, whereas the angular acceleration of \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are \(\alpha_1\) and \(\alpha_2\).
For each of the constraining conditions indicated in the figure, choose the equation(s) that the condition implies.

em.li: Each condition may imply multiple equations, or may imply none of the given equations.
If an equation is not implied by any of the conditions, do not check that equation.

td.p: ideal rope: What is an ideal rope? Ideal ropes do not stretch and all parts of the ideal rope have the same speed. As a consequence, all parts of the ideal rope at left have the same magnitude of acceleration. The objects 1 and 3 (disk and block) connected to the rope also have the same magnitude of acceleration: \(a_1 = a_3\).

ideal rope doesn't slip: What does it mean for the rope to "not slip"? This means there is no relative motion between the pulley's edge and the rope. Consequently, the pully edge and the rope have the same acceleration. Since the rope is ideal, the pulley's edge and object 1 (the disk) have the same acceleration: \(a_1 = \alpha_2 r_2\).

problem.p: A hoop sits on a bus. The bus begins to accelerate toward the right with acceleration \(a_1\), shown below. The bus tires do not slip on the road. As the bus accelerates, the hoop begins to roll without slipping on the rigid floor of the bus and has rightward center of mass acceleration \(a_2\).

ol.li: The bus wheel's radius is \(r_1\). Its center of mass velocity and acceleration are \(v_1\) and \(a_1\); the bus wheel's angular velocity and angular acceleration around its center of mass are \(\omega_1\) and \(\alpha_1\).

The hoop's radius is \(r_2\). Its center of mass velocity and acceleration are \(v_2\) and \(a_2\); the hoop's angular velocity and angular acceleration around its center of mass are \(\omega_2\) and \(\alpha_2\). Point \(P\) on the wheel is in contact with the rigid bus floor.

problem.p: For each of the constraining conditions indicated in the figure, choose the equation(s) that the condition implies.

em.li: Each condition may imply multiple equations, or may imply none of the given equations.
If an equation is not implied by any of the conditions, do not choose that equation.

td.p: hoop rolls without slipping on rigid bus floor: What does this constraint mean? This means that there is no relative motion between the hoop and the bus, i.e., point \(P\) on the wheel has the same velocity as point \(Q\) on the bus floor. Because the bus is a rigid object, point \(Q\) has the same velocity as the rest of the bus, namely \(v_1\). So \(\boxed{v_P=v_1}\). Since point \(P\) and the bus remain at rest relative to each other \(\boxed{a_P=a_1}\).

bus wheels roll without slipping on the road: Again there needs to be no relative motion between the bus wheel's contact point and the road. Since the road is at rest, this requires \( \boxed{v_1 = \omega_1 r_1} \) .

In the following problems, you will need to choose a distance \(r\) and an angle \(\alpha\) that can be used in this expression to give the correct value of \(L\).

problem.p: A particle of mass \(m\) is moving with velocity \(v\) towards a rod of length \(l\) pivoted at one end. The angular momentum of the particle with respect to the pivot of the rod is:
\(L=mvr\sin{(\alpha)}\)
Choose \(r\) and \(\alpha\) to get the correct value for \(L\).

solution.p: Angular momentum \(L\) of a point particle is defined as the cross product between its position vector \(\color{blue}{r}\), which is the vector pointing from the reference point to the particle, and its velocity vector \(\color{#339966}{v}\).

The angle \(\color{magenta}{\alpha}\) in the expression should be the angle between the two vectors as shown in the right figure above. Notice that \(\sin{(\color{#ff00ff}{\alpha})} =\sin{(\pi-\color{#ff00ff}{\alpha})}= \sin{(\alpha_1)}\) (left figure below).
So the correct answer to this problem is shown in the right figure above.

Notice that the expression can also be understood as \(L=mv\color{blue}{[r\sin{(\alpha_1)}]}\), in which \(\color{blue}{r\sin{(\alpha_1)}}\) can be seen as taking the projection of the \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) vector onto the direction perpendicular to the \(\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\) vector, and passing the reference point.

problem.p: A particle of mass \(m\) is moving with velocity \(v\) towards a rod of length \(l\) pivoted at the center of the rod. The angular momentum of the particle with respect to the pivot of the rod is:
\(L=mvr\sin(\alpha)\)

solution.p: In this problem, the position vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) and the velocity vector \(\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\) are in opposite directions, so the angle \(\color{magenta}{\alpha}\) between those two vectors is equal to \(0\)(or \(\pi\) to be exact). Therefore, you should leave the \(\alpha\) pointer undragged. Note that the angular momentum of the particle with respect to the pivot is zero.(See the solution to problem 1 for more detailed explanation).

\(\vec{L}_{particle}=\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\times m\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\)
\(L_{particle}=-m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{r}\sin{(\color{magenta}{\alpha})}\) (The negtive sign is added according to the sign convention)
Vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) is the vector pointing from the reference point to the particle.

The expression for \(L_{particle}\) can also be viewed as: \(L_{particle}=-m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}=mvd\) where \(d=\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\) can be viewed as the length of the projection of vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) onto the direction perpendicular to the velocity vector \(\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\) as shown in the figure above.
In this problem, the length of the projection vector \(\color{blue}{r\sin(\alpha)}\)is equal to \(h\), so our student should use the length of \(h\) for the variable \(d\) in his expression.

p.span: A particle of mass \(m\) is flying with velocity \(v\) towards a square block with side \(a\). The angular momentum of the particle, \(L_{\textrm{particle}}\), depends on the choice of reference point.

In each of the following problems, you are given a math expression representing the angular momentum of the flying particle relative to a certain reference point. The reference point is not shown. Given the value of the angular momentum, your task is to find all possible locations of the reference point consistent with the angular momentum.

You will see multiple versions of the picture above with different possible reference point(s) marked in green. Choose the picture that contains the correct reference point(s) for the expression for \(L\).
If you think none of the positions fits the math expression, choose the blank picture.

vertical.problem:
Angular momentum of the particle
\[\large L_{\textrm{particle}}= - mv(\frac{1}{2}a)\]
Conventions:
Out of page is positive:
Into page is negative:
Which picture shows the correct choice of reference point for the above expression for \(L\)?
Solution:
Explanation:
The angular momentum of the particle with respect to any reference point can be written as:
\(\vec{L_{particle}}=\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\times m\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\)
\(L_{particle}=-m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{[r\sin{(\alpha)]}}\) (The negtive sign is added according to the sign convention)
Vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) is the vector pointing from the reference point to the particle.
The above expression can also be viewed as: \(L_{particle}=-m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\) where \(\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\) can be viewed as the length of the projection of vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) onto the direction perpendicular to the velocity vector \(\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\).
Therefore, for a particle with angular momentum \(L_{particle}=-mv(\frac{1}{2}a)\), the length of its projection vector \(\color{blue}{[r\sin{(\alpha)}]}\) must equal to \(\frac{1}{2}a\). All the reference points satisfying this condition will give the same value for \(L_{particle}\).

Angular momentum of the particle
\[ \large L_{\textrm{particle}}= 0\]
Conventions:
Out of page is positive:
Into page is negative:
Which picture shows the correct choice of reference point for the above expression for \(L\)?
Solution:
Explanation:
For a particle with angular momentum \(L_{particle}=m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}=0\), the length of the projection of position vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}=r\sin(\alpha)}\) must equal to \(0\) (see the solution to the first problem for detailed explanation). Which implies that the possible position for reference points must all lie in the direction of the velocity vector.

Angular momentum of the particle:
\[\large L_{\textrm{particle}}= -mv(r+a)\]
Conventions:
Out of page is positive:
Into page is negative:
Which picture shows the correct choice of reference point for the above expression for \(L\)?
Solution:
Explanation:
For a particle with angular momentum \(L_{particle}=m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}=0\), the length of the projection of position vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}=r\sin(\alpha)}\) must equal to \(r+a\) (see the solution to the first problem for detailed explanation). Or in other words, the vertical distance between the reference point to the particle must equal to \(r+a\). None of the potential targets in this problem satisfies this condition (horizontal distance does not matter for this problem).

Now the particle flies upward between two boxes.
Angular momentum of the particle
\[\large L_{\textrm{particle}}= + mv r\]
Conventions:
Out of page is positive:
Into page is negative:
Which picture shows the correct choice of reference point for the above expression for \(L\)?
Solution:
Explanation:
The angular momentum of the particle with respect to any reference point can be written as:
\(L_{particle}=\pm m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\)
The sign of the angular momentum is determined both by the right hand rule of the cross product, and the convention used in the problem.
For example, in the figure on the left, right hand rule determines that the result of \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\times\vec{v}\) points out of the page. According to the sign convention in the problem, \(L\) is positive.
The magnitude of angular momentum for a particle with given mass and velocity depends on \(\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\), where \(\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\) can be viewed as the length of the projection of vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) onto the direction perpendicular to the velocity vector \(\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\).
Therefore, for a particle with angular momentum \(L_{particle}=-mvr\), the length of its projection vector \(\color{blue}{r\sin(\alpha)}\) must equal to \(r\). All the reference points satisfying this condition will give the same value for \(L_{particle}\).

Angular momentum of the particle
\[\large L_{\textrm{particle}}= - mv\sqrt{r^2+a^2}\]
Conventions:
Out of page is positive:
Into page is negative:
Which picture shows the correct choice of reference point for the above expression for \(L\)?
Solution:
Explanation:
For a particle with angular momentum\(L_{particle}=-m\color{#339966}{v}\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}=-mv\sqrt{r^2+a^2}\), the length of the projection of position vector\(\color{blue}{\vec{r}=r\sin(\alpha)}\) must equal to \(\sqrt{r^2+a^2}\) (see the solution to the first problem for detailed explanation). Or in other words, the vertical distance between the reference point to the particle must equal to \(\sqrt{r^2+a^2}\). None of the potential targets in this problem satisfies this condition (horizontal distance does not matter for this problem).

Now the particle flies upward between two boxes.
Angular momentum of the particle
\[\large L_{\textrm{particle}}= - mv (a+r)\]
Conventions:
Out of page is positive:
Into page is negative:
Which picture shows the correct choice of reference point for the above expression for \(L\)?
Solution:
Explanation:
The sign of the angular momentum is determined both by the right hand rule of the cross product, and the convention used in the problem.
The magnitude of angular momentum for a particle with given mass and velocity depends on \(\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\), where \(\color{blue}{[r\sin(\alpha)]}\) can be viewed as the length of the projection of vector \(\color{blue}{\vec{r}}\) onto the direction perpendicular to the velocity vector \(\color{#339966}{\vec{v}}\) .
Therefore, for a particle with angular momentum \(L_{particle}=-mv(r+a)\), the length of its projection vector \(r\sin(\alpha)\) must equal to \(r+a\). All the reference points satisfying this condition will give the same value for \(L_{particle}\).
(For more detailed explanation see the solution for problem 4)

problem.p: A solid sphere of mass \(m\) and radius \(R\) rolls down a fixed ramp without slipping. The surface of the ramp forms and angle \(\theta\) with the horizon. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sphere and the ramp is \(\mu_k\), and the coefficient of static friction between the sphere and the ramp is \(\mu_s\). The magnitude of the linear acceleration is \(a\) and that of the angular acceleration is \(\alpha\). The rotational inertia is \(I\).

Which of the following equations does not accurately describe this situation? Note: force equations are for the sphere, and the center of mass of the sphere is the reference point for the torque equations.

checkboxgroup.label: Which of the following equations does not accurately describe this situation?

problem.p: Why?

optioninput.label: Why?
optioninput.options: ('It is a solid sphere of mass \(m\) and radius \(R\)','It rolls down a fixed ramp without slipping','The surface of the ramp forms and angle \(\theta\) with the horizon.','The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sphere and the ramp is \(\mu_k\)','The coefficient of static friction between the sphere and the ramp is \(\mu_s\)','Other','Nothing is incorrect.')
optioninput.correct: It rolls down a fixed ramp without slipping

div.p: \(mg\sin{\theta}\) is the component of the gravitational force on the object pointing down the incline; frictional force points up the incline(opposite the object's direction of motion).
This is the angular acceleration for an object that rolls without slipping.
This is the moment of intertia for a solid uniform sphere.

Since the sphere is rolling without slipping, \(\mu_kmg\cos{\theta}\) is always greater than the force of friction. Once you determine the equations for \(\Sigma F = ma\) and \(\Sigma \tau = I\alpha\), you have enough information to solve for acceleration by eliminating frictional force. You never need worry about what the friction force is in this problem.
Torque is the cross-product of the radius and force. If we take the center of the sphere as our reference point, the only force that can produce a torque is the friction force.

div.p: While this may be true, it's not terribly useful because the work done by friction is zero in this problem. Therefore, we don't really have to worry about friction.
The final mechanical energy of the sphere is the same as its final kinetic energy. The potential energy is zero because \(h\) has gone to zero.
Here we have an expression for the kinetic energy of a rolling object.
Hopefully this expression is fairly familiar by now! If not,try rewatching some of the lecture videos.
Hopefully this expression is fairly familiar by now! If not,try rewatching some of the lecture videos.

Since the sphere is rolling without slipping, non-conservative forces do no work overall. Whatever quantity of work friction does to oppose translation, it does in the opposite direction, accelerating rotation. Therefore, the net work done by friction is zero.
Here, U is potential energy. This indicates that the only mechanical energy the sphere had initially was gravitational potential energy. This makes sense because the sphere starts at rest.
This is the formula for gravitational potential energy.
This is the constraint from rolling without slipping.

div.p: Nope, this isn't true. The ramp is frictionless, so there won't be a net torque on the sphere. Therefore, the sphere will still be rotating when it reaches its maximum height,so it will have a nonzero rotational kinetic energy component.
This is the formula for gravitational potential energy.
There is no gravitational potential energy to start (we chose the zero point so that this would be true), so all energy comes from motion, both translational and rotational.

problem.p: The axle is placed on a pair of tracks and the wheel is pulled with a force \(F\) by a string attached to its center. The coefficient of static friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_s\), and the coefficient of kinetic friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_k\). The magnitide of \(F\) is such that the wheel is just about to slip.
Which of the following equations does not accurately describe this situation? Note: take the wheel as the system and the center of the wheel as the reference point for all torques.

checkboxgroup.label: Which of the following equations does not accurately describe this situation?

problem.p: Why?

optioninput.label: Why?
optioninput.options: ('The axle is placed on a pair of tracks.','The wheel is pulled by a string attached to its center with a force \(F\).','The coefficient of static friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_s\).','The coefficient of kinetic friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_k\).','The magnitude of F is such that the wheel is just about to slip.','Other','Nothing is incorrect.')
optioninput.correct: The axle is placed on a pair of tracks.

div.p: Since the frictional force is perpendicular to the radius r drawn from the center of the wheel to the contact point, we have a torque on the wheel due to friction. Remember also that there isn't any torque due to the dragging force because the lever arm is 0, making the cross product of force and lever arm vector equal to zero.

The angular acceleration of an object that is rolling without slipping should be a, the linear acceleration, divided by the radius of rotation In this case the axle, with radius r, is rotating, so \(I\) should be \(\frac{a}{r}\), not \(\frac{a}{R}\).
Total force is the sum of the dragging force and the frictional force, which is in the opposite direction to the direction of motion.
Rolling without slipping means the frictional force is less than or equal to \(\mu_sMg\). Since the wheel is about to slip, frictional \(F_{friction} = \mu_sMg\).

problem.p: The axle is placed on a pair of tracks and the wheel is pulled with a force \(F\) by a string attached to its center. The system starts at rest and is dragged a distance \(D\). During the process the system rolls without slipping. The coefficient of static friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_s\), and the coefficient of kinetic friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_k\). The translational center of mass velocity of the system when it has been dragged for a distance \(D\) is \(v\), and the angular velocity is \(\omega\).
Which of the following equations does not accurately describe this situation? Note: take the wheel as the system.

checkboxgroup.label: Which of the following equations does not accurately describe this situation?

problem.p: Why?

optioninput.label: Why?
optioninput.options: ('The axle is placed on a pair of tracks.','The wheel is pulled by a string attached to its center with a force \(F\).','The system starts from rest and is dragged a distance \(D\).','The system rolls without slipping.','The coefficient of static friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_s\).','The coefficient of kinetic friction between the axle and the tracks is \(\mu_k\).','Other','Nothing is incorrect.')

div.p: All of the equations are correct
Gravitational potential energy has remained constant, so it is not included. Because the wheel is rolling, its kinetic energy has both translational and rotational conponants.
Hopefully this expression is fairly familiar by now! If not,try rewatching some of the lecture videos.
Hopefully this expression is fairly familiar by now! If not,try rewatching some of the lecture videos.
This is the constraint from rolling without slipping.
The wheel was at rest, so it had no kinetic energy. Gravitational potential energy doesn't change throughout the process, therefore we don't include it in our expression.
The applied force \(F\) and the frictional force are the only non-conservative forces involved, so the sum of their works will be the total work done by non-conservative forces.
The direction of the force \(F\) is that same as the direction of the translational motion. Therefore the work done is simply force times distance.

The wheel is rolling without slipping, so frictional force does not do any work on the system. This is because the frictional force acts on the point on the axle that is in contact with the track at any given time. Rolling without slipping ensures that any point that is in contact with the track does not move with respect to the track. Therefore, the distance translated by that contact point during the small period of time, in which there is frictional force acting on it, is zero. Which means that frictional force does not do any work under rolling without slipping condition.
